<p><i><b>La Ronde</b></i> is a 1950 film directed by <a href="/wiki/Max_Oph%C3%BCls" title="Max Oph¨¹ls">Max Oph¨¹ls</a> and based on <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Schnitzler" title="Arthur Schnitzler">Arthur Schnitzler</a>'s 1897 <a href="/wiki/La_Ronde_(play)" title="La Ronde (play)">play of the same name</a>. The title means "the round-dance".</p>
<p>The film was nominated for two <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" title="Academy Award">Academy Awards</a>; for <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Writing_(Adapted_Screenplay)" title="Academy Award for Best Writing (Adapted Screenplay)">Best Writing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award_for_Best_Art_Direction" title="Academy Award for Best Art Direction" class="mw-redirect">Best Art Direction</a> (<a href="/wiki/Jean_d%27Eaubonne" title="Jean d'Eaubonne">Jean d'Eaubonne</a>). <sup id="cite_ref-NY_Times_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY_Times-1"><span>[</span>1<span>]</span></a></sup></p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Plot">Plot</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=La_Ronde_(1950_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Plot">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>It tells a series of stories about love affairs or illicit meetings involving a prostitute, a soldier, a chambermaid, her employer's son, a married woman, her husband, a young girl, a poet, an actress and a count. At the end of each encounter, one of the partners forms a liaison with another person, and so on.</p>
